comments.commentBody:
@ CA

Thank you for sharing that. My story is similar to your own in terms of early education, but I started grade school in the '50s as a young male. The social isolation of the "smart kid" was very severe at the time. And, of course, no "advanced anything" for the gifted students.

The school, even back then, wanted to skip me from first grade to third grade. There was no question that I could do the work of third grade at the time, and in fact, still remain bored. However, my father refused the suggestion, and I am forever grateful to him for doing so. People have a difficult time comprehending the fact that such a seemingly "small step" as jumping from first to third grade is in fact *huge* to the child being affected.

I used to play with those third graders from time to time on the school ground. They were *so* socially advanced relative to my position as a first grader, that they seemed to be an alien species ! It would have been as if I were suddenly going to school with college kids. The idea terrified me.

For the sake of your wonderful sons, I would be very careful about "jumping" them, unless they have some experience of dealing with the kids with whom they would be placed, and you find that they themselves are behind the idea of such a "jump". Especially a jump of two years with your second grader.

Its not necessarily just the uber rich that live on the waterfront, us middle class people live here too.  Thank all the Gods that we inhabit the barrier beaches, they are more robust and protect the mainland from worse disasters.

Don't forget that in many areas where buildings are now uncomfortably close to the water, there once was a wide expanse. I rented an apartment in Sea Gate years ago, a tiny magical studio with a terrace and picture window facing the ocean (which still shows up surprisingly often in my dreams). In the nor'easter of '84, we lost many yards of beachfront; after a hurricane a few years later there was no longer a beach to walk on in high tide. In pictures from the turn of the century, however, the beach seems unimaginably wide.
President Obama does not have to assassinate Mr. Romney's character. He does quite a good job of doing it himself.

Romney has been running a campaign of character assassination and divisiveness for four years. It has been entirely based on lies and distortions, starting with the "apologizing for America" nonsense. Now you complain because the Obama campaign is running negative, but truthful, ads about Romney, his shape-shifting and his lies. The obvious difference between the two is that Obama's ads are truthful.

To accuse someone of character assassination the target should have some character to assassinate. Romney has none.

i don't see how you can say that Obama's record is "dreadful." Impefect - yes. Not up to the level of his campaign rhetoric - yes. Lacking in boldness - somewhat. Dealing with problems instead of making them worse - yes. Excessively ideological - no. coping with a completely recalcitrant Congress - somewhat. If the Democrats hadn't been willing to compromise with Reagan in the country's best interests, Reagan would not now be the hero that many think he was.

I welcome the advent of a decent, sane and responsible conservatism in this country; one that counters the excessiveness of the left-wing rabble-rousing and is based on standards, but it ain't the Republicans.

You argue a completely invalid conclusion by first seeking to establish completely invalid premises.

Your contention that the candidates benefited by left turns is two-dimensional. Romney was portrayed as ultra-right when he is not: when he made clear that he was far more moderate (not left), the electorate was encouraged. Mr. Obama's performance during his first two years, as well as his 2008 manifesto, clearly identified with the far-left; yet his performance since then was forced to be moderate because of ideological resistance by the House -- his return to the left for campaign advantage merely re-energized a base that had almost given up on him.

Then, Republicans NEVER accepted "the premises of the New Deal". They've been consistent that a too-easy evening of living standards divorced from effort is destructive and unsustainable. They've ALWAYS believed "that an increasingly interconnected world will require an increasingly diverse work force". Reagan didn't win due to a left turn; and, if Romney wins, it won't be due to one, either.

Finally, conservatives will not conclude that if Romney loses he wasn't conservative enough: they'll conclude that his strategy didn't succeed at overcoming a counter-campaign by Mr. Obama who, not able to run on a dreadful record, instead focused on character assassination of Mitt Romney. If the president wins, it will be because he succeeded at this strategy, not because he will make the better president these next four years.

Your right that Federal Flood Insurance is taxpayer funded and that it exists to protect people's investment in property that is in flood prone areas. Dee P is correct that the premiums charged for this coverage are relatively expensive - as they should be given the risk to the insurer - the federal government, which will certainly pay out much, much more than it took in from premiums on the damaged properties. Of course, premiums paid by people who did not have a loss will fund the payout to those who had a loss - that's the basic concept of insurance...

But now, you have to ask WHY ordinary insurers won't write this type of insurance... and you have to conclude that it's because they can't make a buck doing it. In fact, most coastal property owners (and even property owners who are substantially removed from the waterfront) in the Northeast can't buy a standard homeowners policy from private insurers - because the number crunchers @ the private companies have done the math and the risk of catastrophic loss is just too great. So, now the States get involved in the insurance business by creating State-backed insurance pools for those properties...

Why? Because without Federally sponsored Flood and State sponsored Property and Casualty insurance, a huge number of homes in the US would be impossible to sell, because you couldn't get a mortgage... so, that would mean no property taxes... and no police, or schools in the affected areas...

The obstacle to abolishing the Electoral College is not the GOP per se; it is the small states with 3 EVs, which are "more" than they "deserve" by strict proportionality to the national population.

Of course most of those 3 EV states are in fact red, but there's also Delaware, VT, and DC (and I would think that if the EC were abolished you'd also have to abolish the 23rd amendment, since it mentions the EC).

From the graphic of Obama's chance of winning, we can measure the electoral college bias against Republicans. What it shows is that Romney would have to win the popular vote by three-quarters (.75) of a percentage point to overcome Obama's advantage in the electoral vote. That is greater than the bias against Democrats in 2000, when Al Gore won the popular vote by one-half point (.51) with 540,000 more popular votes than George W. Bush.

Until now, the Republicans have favored retaining the electoral college, believing that it benefited them. On Tuesday night they may feel differently -- and if so, may be more receptive to abolishing the electoral college. One way would be the traditional route of a constitutional amendment. The other is the National Popular Vote plan, an interstate compact in which participating states agree to give all their electoral votes to the winner of the national popular vote. To date, eight states and the District of Columbia, with a combined 132 electoral votes, have joined NPV.

Once enough states to equal 270 votes join, NPV would go into effect. The result would to make every vote in every state equal in electing the president of the United States.

For Flood insurance, it's all about property taxes...

Towns w/ waterfront have developed their infrastructure on the assumption that the tax base of the "normal" residents of the town would always be subsidized by the high value of properties on the waterfront. They can't afford to lose those valuations - which would certainly happen if buyers couldn't qualify for mortgages because of a lack of Federal & State sponsored insurance pools.

Bigger picture, it's all about government and if it should be structured to share risks among the greater population for the greater good.

No?

Fine, you want to be a farmer? They you can pay out of your pocket every time your crop fails. No more Federal Crop Insurance. No private companies willing to underwrite? No food for the cities.

Fine, you want to generate electricity from a Nuclear power plant? They you can pay out of your pocket if your plant melts down and makes every property 20 mile radius uninhabitable for 50 years . No private companies willing to underwrite without a liability limit from the Feds? Shut 'er down, shut 'er down, shut 'er down.

Libertarians hate federally backed insurance - right up until it's THEIR federally backed insurance....

Yes, President Obama has dealt with the man-made economic disaster that George W. Bush left behind and has our economy up and running again.  He has also dealt with several natural disasters, humanely and competently.  I think this man deserves re-election over a vulture capitalist who wants to let the stricken states handles disasters or better yet the private sector.
No government, no civilization. No socialism, no civilization. It is not the state that is a problem, but the state of the state. And to the gravest problems, only the state can bring a solution.

I am sorry that there is such animosity toward runners, who I think were basically pawns in this. Not to pile on, I have only two points to make:

1. Unlike the statement that continues to be made both by the mayor and NYRR on its website and in its message to us members, it is impossible to think that the race would not have diverted needed resources from the recovery. And the proof is that NYRR is now donating food, clothing, equipment etc. to the recovery, so they could have done that immediately.

2. Does the mayor really not see the differences between running a marathon nearly two months after September 11 when there was no more "recovery" ongoing except on the site itself and this, less than a week after the storm when people are still lacking power, heat, food, homes, possibly life? (Of course our ex-mayor would support this grandiose idea.)

(by the way, the actual first running event held in Central Park after September 11 was the Grete Waitz half marathon held about a month after that attack. I did it and it was very emotional, and healing. That was the right thing to do. This marathon was just wrong--too bad it wasn't obvious with just a bit of thought.)

I'll take a shot at this question. The discrepancies probably arise in determinations of who is likely to vote. Republicans are more likely to vote, overall, but the determination of how big an allowance to make for that is still apparently more art than science.

Also, as Nate has mentioned recently, robo-calling is not allowed to cellphones. So polling which depends upon robo-calling only miss many people, mostly younger people more likely to be Democrats than Republicans.

Apparently state polls, focusing on a smaller population, are able to do more to avoid these two problem areas.

The apparent ending of most of the divergence between state and national polls, which Nate reports in today's blog, is, he suggests, suspect in that it may reflect last-minute adjustments to methodology in processing the data. Such tinkering is bad polling and bad statistical work, and it is a shame that polling organization may be indulging in such shenanigans to avoid appearing too far off in their estimates when compared with actual results.

"I hate big government" - Randspeak-to-English translation: I hate any government activity that costs me money and does not directly benefit me and people like me or that might help some group of people I do not like.
Faux conservatives love big government when it is enforcing policies that reward companies for sending decent jobs to emerging markets, or pad corporate profits with subsidies and tax shelters. They really, really, really love government when it is throwing billions at cost plus weapons designed to fight the USSR or prisons for profit. But when it comes to providing services that actually help people, even services that can ONLY be done by government, then it is all "socialism". They use Ayn Rand's ludicrous social philosophy as a psuedointellectual justification for their own selfishness, prejudices and irrational fears.
After 30 plus years of this hollow rhetoric, I think most Americans are finally seeing it for what it is, a bumper sticker, and not an appropriate basis for a system of modern governance.
Now, can we finally, finally discuss the realities and science behind human influenced global warming and what we can do about it? And yes, this is also something that can only realistically be done by government, governments in fact. Chris Christie has provided the GOP an example of what acting like a adult is like, I hope they can learn from this and we can take global warming as seriously and urgently as it deserves to be.
